Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Impacts of Mechanized Agriculture on Smallholders and Landscapes in the Central Amazon Basin

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This doctoral dissertation research project will examine the social and environmental implications of smallholder displacement by mechanized soy farming for an important agricultural frontier in the central Amazon Basin. Mechanized soybean farming has recently crept towards the Amazon Basin, and there is growing concern about the consequences of this expansion on the rainforest. Past research generally has focused on environmental impacts, namely deforestation via direct encroachments and indirect land-use change at a regional scale. As a result, less is known about the welfare impacts of soybean expansion or about more localized and nuanced land-change outcomes, particularly those associated with smallholder displacement. The doctoral student will focus on social and environmental processes stemming from such displacements in the central Amazon near the city of Santarem. He will conduct research that seeks to describe the circumstances under which such displacements occurred, such as whether land was sold at fair market value or was transferred without adequate compensation via coercion. The student also will address land changes associated with soybean expansion in the central basin. To this end, he will study the conversion of primary and secondary rainforests on properties transferred from smallholders to soybean interests, and he will examine the deforestation occurring in new frontiers created by the in-migration of smallholders from areas of soybean consolidation. Research methods will include a survey of smallholders in order to describe the process of land transfer and to ascertain their destination choices upon land transfer to soybean interests as well as analyses of remotely sensed imagery to determine land-change impacts.

This project will address social processes and complex interactions involving multiple agents and their subsequent impacts on the Amazon landscape. The project will contribute to development of land-change science, which has been long dominated by a paradigm focused on land managers acting in isolation. This project will help expand this paradigm by showing how multiple land-change outcomes occurring on properties sold and on newly acquired holdings can result from a single land sale, and it can describe how land change occurs as a result of multiple agents and social processes impacted by power relations. Project results should have policy implications, because little is known about the welfare effects of soybean mechanization, particularly with respect to smallholders. Information generated by this project should contribute to policy debates regarding ways to balance development and the environment in the Amazon. As a Doctoral Dissertation Research Improvement award, this project will provide support to enable a promising student to establish an independent research career.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes Report

This doctoral dissertation research project examined the social and environmental implications of smallholder displacement by soybean farming in the central Amazon Basin of Brazil. Over the past several decades, mechanized agriculture has expanded northwards, and there is growing concern about the consequences for Amazonia. Research to date generally focuses on environmental impacts, namely deforestation via direct encroachments and indirect land-use change at a regional scale. As a result, less is known about the welfare impacts of soybean expansion or about more localized and nuanced land change outcomes, particularly those associated with smallholder displacement. In order to shed light on these possible outcomes, we surveyed smallholders who sold to soybean farmers in the Santarem region. The survey instrument was composed of a set of inquiries addressing land transfers and destination choices for smallholders leaving their properties after sale. With a sample of sixty interviews (n = 60), we identified three migration possibilities, namely individuals moving to urban environments; to adjacent rural locations, and to forest frontiers. Most (n = 34) chose to remain in rural areas.

The project sought to describe the circumstances under which displacements occurred. We found that the majority of land transfers took place through market transactions. Although only one case of coercion was reported, smallholders whose properties were encircled by soybean plantations found themselves desiring to sell, as pesticide use and fertilizer runoff damaged their land, crops and livestock. In these situations, smallholders did not receive a fair market value for their land, although they did profit by land sale, thereby enhancing their disposable income and savings.

The project also addressed regional land changes associated with the process of soybean expansion. We focused on the conversion of primary and secondary rainforests on the properties the smallholders sold, and the indirect land use impacts in the frontier areas to where they migrated upon displacement. We found that conversion of primary and secondary rainforests on properties transferred from smallholders to soybean interests was uniform and complete. Usually, remaining forest on consolidated holdings was entirely cleared to make way for crops. In addition, displaced smallholders who resettled in forest frontiers (16% of the sample) cleared primary forests at their new locations. 

We found that smallholders who sold land to soybean farmers, except those migrating to forest frontiers, downsized their lots and reconstituted them near former properties. In many cases, they moved to adjacent communities that offered desirable amenities such as electricity and schools. The choice to move to urban areas was predominant when the head of the household was sixty or more years of age. Income earned from the land sale did not play a significant role in destination choice.

This project furthered international collaboration with local institutions such as the Institute of the People and Integrated Studies of the Amazon-INEA and the Federal University of Western Amazonia-UFOPA. INEA collaborated by sharing their knowledge of the region and by providing logistical support to the fieldwork; UFOPA helped by furnishing undergraduate students as research assistants.
